Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 12:31PM LauraOntario wrote: Elizabeth, Sorry you got interrogated.   As for the use of words...my Mom and I moved back to Scotland for a year after my Dad died.  I was on the subway and I heard some kids saying they were just "knackered."  I thought this was a cute little Scottish word for tired and I told my Mom about it and we started using it all the time.  Turns out it wasn't a very nice Scottish word.  We said it to the Minister and the missionaries who came over for tea.  We were saying things like "That missionary work must have made you knackered."  Oh well, what can you do?

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2013 02:47PM LauraOntario wrote: Hi there, I think about this all the time.  If it were up to me, I would stop all treatment right now and just pass away.  But, that's because I'm depressed.  What stops me is my religion.  I am a Roman Catholic and want to know what to do as far as what God expects of me.  I spoke to my parish priest about it and he said I can quit treatment at any time if death is inevitable.  This didn't sound right to me because of the Church's emphasis on preserving life.  So, I wrote to the Vatican and asked for advice, and they told me to speak to my parish priest. The thing is, I have bone mets and could live for many years.  I don't want to throw my life away because I am feeling down right now.  And, I do have some pleasure in life.  My cat, Buddy, just discovered rubber bands as I was typing this.  He makes me laugh every day.  We're not in an easy positon.  I guess, like has been said, there is an inner voice that will, hopefully, speak to us and let us know.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2012 04:43AM LauraOntario wrote: My brother and his family have been very good to me, but I am definitely the outsider amongst his family.  I never married and had my own family.  My sister died of lung cancer in 2004 and my Mom and Dad are both gone.  I know how it feels to feel so lonely.  I actually wish I could just go sometimes and be with the people I was closest to.  My brother and his family really don't like me.  I just tell you this to know you are not alone.  Don't be hurt.  Although, sometimes a good cry can really help.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2013 08:02AM LauraOntario wrote: Barb, I had my two year anniversary in April.  Like you, I thought I would be long gone by now.  Now I realize that I don't have to lie down and wait to die with cancer, but get up and learn to live with cancer.  I've been lucky with side effects, though, and I really feel for those who are suffering from bad ones.  I know that with bone mets I probably have a lot of pain waiting for me in the future, but I'm going to deal with that when it happens.  Take care, Laura
Posts.Title: TWO years and counting! barsco1963 Leah_S

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2014 11:39AM LauraOntario wrote: Thanks, Ladies.  It's nice to hear that I'm not alone. I like to hear it when people tell me I'm brave and everything, but I'm really not.  I want to go for a long period of feeling good and a setback really gets to me now. Well, thanks again.  Laura.
Posts.Title: One thing after another. LauraOntario Zillsnot4me

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 02:23AM LauraOntario wrote: They refuse here to give my 30 year-old niece a mammogram because she is so young.  I was diagnosed at the age of 45, and my sister (her Mum) died of lung cancer at 47.  Her grandmother died of Non-Hodgkins lymphoma at 73.  Her father had a cancer scare in his early twenties.  She is really scared and I don't see what harm it would do to let her be tested.
Posts.Title: "Awareness" rant! kayrnic AmyJM
